headline.main: London Journal; U.S. Eating Habits, and Europeans, Are Spreading Visibly

docs.abstract: Europeans are fast catching up with American reputation for being overweight; in Britain, percentage of obese adults is three times what it was just two decades ago, fastest-growing rate in Western Europe; experts cite sedentary lifestyles, environment where adults and children are bombarded with commercials for sugary foods and, most of all, fact that American jumbo-size portions are now common in Europe; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Mickey and Clement Dabadie gazed down at their box of a dozen fresh, flaky doughnuts, glazed and filled, and savored the prospect of every calorie-pumped morsel, guilt-free. They had driven to Harrods, the luxury goods department store, specifically to stand in line for Krispy Kreme doughnuts, and now was not the time to fume over fat grams. ''If you're going to feel guilty, don't eat them,'' Mrs. Dabadie, 31, who works at a London hair salon, said on a recent day. ''And if you want to lose weight, just don't eat doughnuts. It's a bit of rubbish to blame the food.''
